fields.summary: API to Retrieve Build Comments

fields.description:
Bamboo has a tab for each build called "Changes," which allows you to see what has changed since the previous build.  This is a great feature.  Sometimes however, we wish to know what has changed from 10 builds ago.  This is often the case during release cycles or drops to QA, where we need to generate a report of what has been fixed/updated/added since the last drop.

This feature should allow me to select two arbitrary builds (from the same plan) and show the changes between them.

A suggested implementation in the UI would be to add functionality to the current "Changes" tab.  It should allow the user to select any build (i.e. other than the immediately previous build) from which to show the changes.  The UI would then be updated and display changes like usual, only they would span a gap of more than 1 build.
fields.summary: Change Log Between Arbitrary Builds

fields.description:
By default, Bamboo turns off build queues before export (so that builds do not get kicked off in the middle of a export) and if exports fail, then a exception is thrown and Bamboo does't turn the build queues back on again.

This means, users can't perform (scheduled) backups if LDAP is enabled as the build queues would remain disabled if backups fail.

Please see support issue BAM-1513
fields.summary: Bamboo leaves build queue's in a disabled state, if exports (scheduled backups) fail

fields.description:
The build plan summary page is a fantastic place to see trending over time.  Duration, failed tests, etc are all a good start.  There are lots of other trending metrics that would be fantastic to expose at that level, for example:

 * Lines of Code
 * Number of Tests
 * Code Coverage
 * Number of code tangles/cycles

[The first three of these are available as reports.]

You can imagine many others, especially when you consider all of the static analysis tools out there (find bugs, pmd, etc).  Maven makes integrating these tools quite easy, so the raw data is pretty easily available.  Now we just need a consistent and consolidated view of that data. :)

Have you considered opening the plugin api so that we could write plugins which contribute to this summary page?

_Even better_, what about being able to embed any report/graph from the reports section into the summary page?  Possibly providing "portlet" style customization (like Jira's dashboard) so that we could easily customize the summary page.  The beauty is that plugin authors could support adding new report/graphs types, and then they'd automatically be available for embedding if desired.

The idea of having a single page to monitor code health metrics over time is awfully attractive.  Maybe it's not the Summary page, but rather, a sibling Metrics page (or Reports)... this way the Summary page stays simple and users can embed all of their geeky stats for the plan in one place.

Before you say it: Sure, we can point people to the maven site which includes all of this information, but it's not aggregated and it's a pain to get trending over time.  Not to mention that doesn't help those who are using Ant or some other build system.
fields.summary: Customizable plan summary tab/page
Lock-up on BEAC

fields.description:
These are the 2 most popular links most users will click - I click them all the time. Yet I rarely use others on the Nav Bar like Home / Authors / Create Plan.

Right now I have to go to Home, then often click another link (which is a tad painful). 

I never look at authors; I rarely look at Reports and my only reason for going to Home is to click on these 2 links. So I think it'd save folks a bit of clicking if we updated the nav bar some? Or at least make it configurable
fields.summary: should have links to 'Current Activity' and 'All Plans' on the nav bar

fields.description:
We have our Bamboo instance integrated with Fisheye, such that when looking at a particular build, we cat click on the Changes tab and immediately click through to the changed files in Fisheye, or better yet, to their diffs.

However, when getting notified from Bamboo via IM that a build has completed, responding to the IM with 'changes' only returns me the submission comment.

I'd love to see it return the same links that the web UI does, so I can navigate to Fisheye directly from my IM client.

Thanks!
fields.summary: changes command - return links to changed files as well as comments

fields.description:
Currently the build log for an individual build is taken from the activity logs and xStreamed as part of the build results. The problem with this is two fold:

# Unbounded activity log - the build log can be arbitrarily large so the activity log is unbounded by default and cleared when a build starts. If a build *never* starts, and just keeps logging, you'll run out of memory pretty quick. We should use a FIFO bounded buffer for the activity logs instead. 
# Build log is part of the buildresultsNN.xml - Which means a whole heap of memory is wasted on the caching & xStreaming of logs. This is slow and unnecessary. The build logs should be streamed to disk and stored as text as an artifact to the build.
fields.summary: Build logs should be separated from the activity logs

fields.summary: Have a nicer Error page, when trying to see a non existing build report

fields.description:
On the page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Getting+Bamboo+Standalone+to+use+the+jetty.xml+file

The RUN_CMD should be

RUN_CMD="java \-Xms256m \-Xmx512m \-Djava.awt.headless=true \-classpath $CLASSPATH \-Dorg.mortbay.xml.XmlParser.NotValidating=true com.atlassian.bamboo.server.Server webapp/WEB-INF/classes/jetty.xml
fields.summary: documenting usage of jetty.xml file

fields.description: We've noticed on two occasions that all of our build queues become disabled.  There is no hint of this in the logs and I don't see any calls to deactivate.action - so none of my admins are doing it.  How can we further diagnose this?  Is this a known issue?
fields.summary: Build queues become disabled randomly

fields.description:
Currently, users can't specify build numbers to match the revision numbers of their applications/softwares.

Perhaps, users can be given an option to specify base build (revision) number for their plans and bamboo would increment future builds as required.

From https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-180,
{quote}
Hi have an product which exists quite some time, and thus it has already a high build version number.

E.g. Produkt Version build number 755

We want to force bamboo to take for the next build a number higher than this value (e.g. 760, at the moment the last build has the build number 13, (only for one time)
{quote}
fields.summary: Ability to specify build(revision) numbers for plans in Bamboo

fields.description:
I realise that this release doesn't support DB2. However, we are a DB2 shop and having purchased licences for Jira, Confluence and Bamboo it would be nice if the tool suite had consistent database support . That is, both Jira and Confluence support DB2, why not Bamboo?

An install was attempted against DB 8.1.11 Express Edition using the unsupported database option. Installation was abandoned after numerous problems related to table creation during server startup. The following tables couold not be created:
COMMENT - column definition needs to be 'CONTENT clob(2147483647) NOT LOGGED'
COMMIT - COMMENT varchar(4000) causes problems due to record size being greater than the default tablespace of 4K, can column be smaller?
BUILD_DEFINITION - XML_DATA varchar(4000) exceeds default tablespace size
BUILD_DEFINITION - column definition needs to be 'BUILD_ID bigint NOT NULL unique'
BUILDRESULTSUMMARY_CUSTOMDATA - CUSTOM_INFO_DATA varchar(4000) exceeds default tablespace size
NOTIFICATION_RULES - column name 'NOTIFICATION_EVENT_CONDITION_KEY' is too long, DB2 has a 30 character limit
NOTIFICATION_RULES - column 'NOTIFICATION_EVENT_CONDITION_META_INFO' has the problems of name being too long and the varchar(4000) will probably cause problems with the default tablespace size
fields.summary: DB2 support

fields.description:
Currently, a build which failed because the parser cannot parse the test files will say "No tests found ... "

A more appropriate message may be "Some test files were found, but they could not be parsed."
fields.summary: Test Parsing Error Should be reflected in Build Error Log

fields.description: You currently have to restart Bamboo if you import during the setup process. This shouldn't really be necessary and it makes functionally testing import / export quite difficult.
fields.summary: Ability to import data during setup without restarting

fields.description:
When subscribing to the "All builds" RSS feed, the builds are sorted in ascending order and the latest build is not on top of all builds.

Where as all other feeds are sorted in descending order,
fields.summary: The plan level "All builds" rss feed is not sorted in the right chronological order.

fields.description:
The right arrow in the screenshot has some greyish pixels on the right-hand side.

Not sure why that is. The image itself (/images/build_nav_arrow_right.gif) doesn't have this artifact.
fields.summary: Next build arrow image has stray pixels

fields.description: Currently the backups are scheduled by giving a time and a period. The period starts when you turn it on, so if we want the backups to happen on a friday, I have to set the period to 7 days and enable it on a friday. I think that using a cron expression to specify the time/day(s) would be much more useful and flexible.
fields.summary: Scheduled backups should use cron triggers rather than time and period

fields.description: Administrators should have the ability to change a user's password in Bamboo
fields.summary: Change a user's password

fields.description: Coverage currently isn't picked up if a build fails. A better alternative which may not affect the accuracy of the data as much is to check whether clover artifacts exist rather than using the build status. In Clover, coverage is still recorded for failing tests.
fields.summary: Clover coverage should be picked up even when build fails

fields.description:
Description of the "Override global build expiry configuration" checkbox reads:

bq. This will enable and override build *exiry* for this build
fields.summary: Typo on "Post Actions" tab

fields.description:
Issue raised on behalf of Magnus
{quote}
> When supplying system environment variables I write them in a 
> comma-separated list in the textfield. Another option would be to use a 
> multi-lined textbox with each property on a separate line. Furthermore 
> it could be emphasized that e.g. Ant properties are to be supplied in 
> this field.
{quote}
fields.summary: Add seperate text boxes for each 'System Environment variable' in PLAN -> Build configuration page

fields.description: Currently during installation, under starting data, it says 'Import existing data ', 'Specify the absolute path to the file on the server from which Bamboo is to import.'. It doesn't however specify what - the old /dev folder within /bamboo folder, the xml-data folder, the checkout folder, the folder containing build results - it isn't very clear. could do with defining it further
fields.summary: More clarity for upgrade

fields.description: At the moment you can setup a Bamboo instance with no name, which makes certain screens look a bit silly
fields.summary: Bamboo instance name should be mandatory and default to Atlassian Bamboo

fields.description: The distribution for Bamboo is complete. To finish the hand over to cross product all packaging/release configuration needs to be removed in TRUNK before 1.2.2.
fields.summary: Remove all release configuration from Bamboo

fields.summary: Exception thrown when browsing build results

fields.description: It would be great to have build expiration be conditional, perhaps based on the tags associated with a build.  For instance, when we release a build I tag that build "release" then if I could go to the expiration page and say "don't expire builds with the 'release' tag"  Then I could make sure we don't lose our released builds.
fields.summary: Conditional build expiration

fields.description:
I used my old atlassian-user.xml from 1.1 that uses an extern LDAP connection for user authentication. 1.2  Displays an error page in the users page, altough it is usable.
Attached log of the error.
fields.summary: FreeMarker template error in user listing with external AD connection

fields.description: From http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WW/S2-001 and http://issues.apache.org/struts/browse/WW-2030
fields.summary: Webwork 2.2.2 security exploit.

fields.description: Our docs indicate that the JDBC jar should be placed in common/lib.  Since Bamboo does not use Tomcat, this is incorrect.  For Jetty, the jar needs to be placed in webapp/WEB-INF/lib.
fields.summary: External Database Docs are Incorrect

fields.description:
Moving to our new build box via export/import lost all dependencies information from the plans. I assume this isn't intentional.

It's pretty hard to enter, too. Need to raise a feature request to improve the UI.
fields.summary: Plan dependencies not exported or imported (not sure which)

fields.description:
As a work around for repositories not supported by Bamboo - it would be helpful if users could define a null repository or point to project(s) on local file system.

This could also be used for evaluation purposes for customers evaluating Bamboo.

From, http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257250332#257250332
fields.summary: Option to define a null repository or point to a project on the local file system, when configuring plans.

fields.description:
Please see BAM-957 for further reference.
{quote}
Tried using it with the same Oracle 9 database that I am using for Jira and Confluence. On the "Configure Database" page I get the following error message:

Database configuration failed: Schema creation complete, but tables could not be found.

and indeed, the tables are not in the database.

Looking in the log indicates that:

(a) the PostgreSQLDialect was being used. Given that the install routine never asked what type of database would be used, there was little chance that the Oracle dialect would be the default. And therefore all of the "invalid datatype" messages.

(b) there is at least one identifier that is over Oracle's inane 30 character limit. Therefore the "invalid identifier" message.

Hopefully this information will help in reaching a "Oracle Compliant" mode quickly.

fields.summary: verify the comment on the 'LDAP' page and update the doc if appropriate
Bamboo Plan key must be able to accept lower case and seperators

fields.description:
I am attempting to backup Bamboo in order to convert to using an external DB (Postgres).  When running the export, I am receiving a "Export has failed. Errors encountered while exporting." error on the export interface.  The atlassian-bamboo.log is attached below.  We have LDAP configured.  I noticed on the LDAP FAQ page that LDAP shoudl be turned off during the export procedure.  I am unable to turn off LDAP because after doing so because Bamboo will not restart.  I have included the bamboo.log file as well. 

Please help!

Thanks

fields.summary: Unable to export/backup Bamboo

fields.description:
As per BSP-163,


The POM's in Bamboo 1.2 need to be updated with correct repositories for.

Artifact com.atlassian.johnson:atlassian-johnson:jar:0.6

AND

Artifact com.atlassian.bucket:atlassian-bucket:jar:0.11
fields.summary: Bamboo POM's need to be updated for the next point release

fields.description:
When Bamboo is integrated with LDAP (with very large users/groups), performance is hit on the users/groups page, as it takes a long time to load groups and users.

Originally a support issue BSP-92
fields.summary: View users page slow since it displays all groups. Needs a group picker

fields.description:
It would be useful, if users could import eclipse projects into Bamboo. 

Perhaps we could provide a plan configuration plugin point, for users to write plugins to suit their needs.

Originally a forum issue http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257250064#257250064
{quote}
I have a program with multiple, independent SVN projects. Development
is performed in eclipse CDT with GNU makefiles, and developers use eclipse
project settings to provide environment variables to the make. I.e., some
projects depend on other projects for includes and libraries.

I'm struggling with a way of making this work with Bamboo that doesn't
require me to duplicate the eclipse settings in the Bamboo Builder
Configuration, because I know that will eventually get out of sync and
cause headaches.
{quote}
fields.summary: Port/sync eclipse projects to Bamboo

fields.description:
Currently, plans configuration are validated before they are placed in a queue. Any errors are logged to the standard error handler. This means that people monitoring the live activity logs don't get *any* insight to why their builds were rejected.

We should make sure that the errors are logged to the live build logs and also the log4j logs as well
fields.summary: Configuration validation failure should have more prominent warnings
Automatic killing of builds if user input is detected
Slow performance on test results page.

fields.description: Exports fails with an exception when Bamboo is building and returns to the UI with a generic error message, users should be advised to stop builds while exporting Bamboo data.
fields.summary: Vague error when exporting while building

fields.description: The imported build work directory will be used instead.
fields.summary: Importing from a different server from builds pre: 406 causes inconsistent build directories

fields.description:
If you upgrade the Bamboo from 1.0.x to 1.2 directly, it will fail.

There are two workarounds:
# Stop and restart Bamboo. This will rerun the upgrade tasks and things should work fine
# Upgrade to 1.1.2 and then upgrade to 1.2
fields.summary: Upogrades from 1.0.x directly to 1.2 fails
Splitting of logs

fields.summary: Bamboo import failure

fields.description: It's not clear if Build Logs will be expired when you choose to expire build artificts.  My guess is they aren't expired.  It would be nice if you had the option to expire the logs (but leave the build result for analysis).
fields.summary: Option to Expire Build Logs

fields.description: It's confusing that administration options are in so many different places.  One would think that you could administer plans by clicking 'Administer' in the top navbar.  It would be very nice if all the per-plan administration options were also available from that administration screen, so you don't have to click back & forth among very different places in order to administer Bamboo.  What would be especially nice is if in the global area under Administer, it showed you which plans were overriding these default values too.
fields.summary: Administration Options Are Confusing

fields.description:
When successfully completing an export, the info box says the time taken to do the export has the "Time Taken" duplicated.

Please see the attachment.
fields.summary: "Time Taken" duplication on successful export
Error message that appears when a invalid build label is entered doesn't mention whitespace.

fields.description: Bamboo 1.2 added permissions per plan. Unlike JIRA, there're no "schemes" as such to share the configuration, thus there's a real need to be able to bulk edit permissions.
fields.summary: Bulk edit of permissions
User commments should have the standard link formatting applied to it

fields.description: Build plans in Bamboo allow groups to be specified as recipients of build notifications.  It appears that the implicit behavior for group notifications is to send the notification via email.  I would like to specify that a group be notified by IM instead of email.  My current workaround is to enumerate all the jabber addresses of team members in the "instant message addresses" text box of the build notification tab but this is not easily maintainable.
fields.summary: Group IM Notification

fields.description:
Ruby tests are written like this:
{code}
def test_can_open_metadata
  # Test
end
{code}

When the Test::Unit tests are run through CI Reporter and played on Bamboo, they show up like {{_test_can_open_metadata}}.  A Java test named {{testCanOpenMetadata()}} would show up as _Can Open Metadata_, which is nice from a legibility perspective.  Would be nice if Bamboo could do the same with ruby test methods, so t hat it would show up as _Can Open Metadata_ as well.

This is just one more way that Bamboo could enhance its support for Ruby on Rails development.
fields.summary: Reformat underscore-style test names
Map Jabber address to bamboo users via LDAP

fields.description: When you comment on a build result, line breaks are lost which means that multi-line comments are displayed as a single line
fields.summary: Line breaks are lost in user comments

fields.description:
You can add multiple build labels of the same name for a build result, which then cannot be deleted

# Click add label
# Type in "test clean"
# Hit enter a few times

then boom!
fields.summary: It's possible to add dupicate labels for a build result you then can't remove them

fields.description:
Bamboo should update webDav with the build results once built

See, http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257249868#257249868
fields.summary: Bamboo should update webDav with the build results once built

fields.description:
We have a dependency tree with two projects, A & B where B depends on A. 

A developer checks in code in both projects. Bamboo will not build these in any particular order since we are using repository polling. The dependency ordering just spawns new dependency builds, but does not perform any sort of ordering.

If a commit modifies A and B in a dependent way, what should happen is that A should be built prior to B. What happens is that Bamboo could pickup B prior to A, perform the B build and fail since A hasn't built yet, then build A since it was modified as well, then kick off a dependency build for B, which then passes.

Ideally, there should be an option to tell Bamboo that since B depends on A, prior to building B, check that A is up to date and built. We need this since the artifacts of builds are published in an ivy repository, so the B build doesn't know anything about A except where to get the published successful build.

A secondary option that would follow from this feature would be a blocked state. If project A fails tests, then any dependent projects should enter a blocked state until A passes.

So instead of just a dependency on the plan config, perhaps a set of dependency options, such as "depends"(current impl), "depends with parent checking", and "depends with parent check and blocking"
fields.summary: Dependencies should check parents for modifications prior to build

From, https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-113

Currently, only one builder can be configured against each plan and it would be nice to be able to configure more than one builder per plan.

Discussed in http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257249682#257249682
fields.summary: Multiple builders per plan

fields.description:
I had a running version of Bamboo 1.0.5 with several build plans. On the adminstration page I had our SMTP server configured (just the server name - no username/password). Sending emails worked fine.

After upgrading to 1.1.2 failing build did not send any emails any more. When I then tested the email settings on the admin page I keep getting:

"The mail settings you entered were not valid. Error thrown was: null"

I tried to change to an SMTP server with authentication, but that did not help either.

When testing the email server no log message appears in atlassian-bamboo.log. However, I found this error at the end of all excuted builds:

2007-06-29 14:57:43,870 ERROR [BAM::Default Queue::BuildComp] [EmailListener] Failed to find mail server


I tried to downgrade, but this did not help.
fields.summary: Unable to configure email server after upgrade from 1.0.5. to 1.2.2

fields.description:
Currently, passwords are sent over as plain text. 

As requested in http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257248717#257248717, it would be useful if Bamboo shipped with NTLM authentication functionality for LDAP.
fields.summary: NTLM authentication for LDAP
Perforce change logs not picked up due to update returning too many results.

fields.description:
As an improvement to the low disk usage plugin, it would be helpful if Bamboo threw meaningful errors when builds fail due to full disk.

Discussed in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-149
fields.summary: Bamboo should throw a meaningful error if it fails due to full disk

fields.description: It would be very nice if Bamboo's war file could be built similarly as in Jira.   That way Bamboo plugins, customizations, etc can be prepackaged into the war before deployment.
fields.summary: WAR build mechanism like Jira

fields.description:
The broken build e-mails in bamboo would be a lot more helpful if they included more context on why the build broke.  We have a large team (50+ developers) and it's not always obvious if your change broke the build, especially if it's a downstream component or an integration test.

Right now all the e-mail says is: The build has 1 failed test and 90 successful tests.

The Bamboo build page gives great info about new/old/fixed tests, why not include that in the e-mail?  

There is a similar problem with compile failures, all it says is that "No failed tests found, a possible compilation error."  Not sure if that's specific to maven2 builds or not.

This feature would be great for big teams - I get 25+ build message a day for broken/fixed builds and it would be great to know which ones I might have caused.
fields.summary: Add more detail to the broken build e-mail - compiler error or broken test

fields.description:
It appears that CVS updates don't occur on the build queue threads, but instead occur on their own thread.

However, that means that if 1 plan is doing a checkout, then the other plans can't even start to build.

I can't see any logical reason for this - I've got multiple build queues for a reason, why doesn't the SCM check out use them?

Some of our projects take a few minutes to update, so this is a significant issue for us (until we move to a more friendly SCM repository).
fields.summary: Allow multiple build plans to be updating from SCM at the same time

fields.description: Bamboo needs an option to download the log's output as a file.  Some build log outputs are *huge* (with five capital H's).  Opening them in Firefox or IE can take a very long time, and selecting them in FireFox or IE can freeze/crash them.  These logs could be grepped locally more easily than through a browser interface.
fields.summary: Log Output Download Option

fields.description:
Bamboo uses a ton of disk space, with no easy way to keep it to a managable level.  The logs for running it are constantly inflating with output of checking the repositories for updates.  Fortunately it seems to limit the filesize to 20MB, and keeps only 5 levels of history for a total of 80MB of logs.  That's an upfront cost that should never change.  It would be nice if these logs grew at a slower pace (or if there was an option to reduce the amount of logged info.)

Build output can grow beyond reason, though.  It's often useful to have a continuous build that has logging turned on, so you can see what's going wrong when something goes wrong, but each build can then balloon in size.  We're at a point where Bamboo writes ~1GB per day.  We've temporarily set the builds to expire every 2 weeks, but that isn't an ideal situation -- we really want to keep them around forever (or close to forever).

Some suggestions for managing ballooning disk space:
 - Archive builds older than X days, unarchived upon request (spidering disabled, etc..).
 - Store build output in zipped format, unzipped upon request.
 - Enable finer-grained expiry controls pt 1.  (Per project, plan, on-demand build, etc..)
 - Enable finer-grained expiry controls pt 2.  (Options to expire only: selected artifacts, log output, test results, etc...)

I'm sure there's a ton of other things that can be done too.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Reduce Bamboo's Disk Space Requirements

fields.description:
I've used Cruise Control with subversion for several years.  We like to have code exported rather than checked out, so each build is from scratch.  Cruise provided the modificationset which allowed for checking a repository for changes but not checking out the code.  It does this by executing svn log between the build time and the last successful build.  What I'm asking for is something similar.  Where the build strategy can be to poll the repo (or multiple repos - BAM-866) but not checkout the code.  So, the repository could be set to none.

Another alternative would be to allow an svn export from the Source Repository when svn is chosen.
fields.summary: Separate the Build Strategy from the repository configuration.

fields.description:
It would be really useful to have a time limit on plans so that if it this time is exceeded, the build is forcibly stopped (by actually terminating the process) and the plan is marked as failed.

We occasionally have builds which just get stuck while doing unit testing (due to, say an error in a unit test). Unfortunately, this will block all other plans on the server until someone manually kills it (and even then the only way I've been able to do this with bamboo is by killing  the actual process).
fields.summary: Have a time limit on builds

fields.description: You should be able to reply to the Jabber notifications to get more information about the commit that caused the build
fields.summary: New Jabber command for getting more change logs information

fields.description: I always seem to find myself looking for the 'Build Actions' menu on the results page, then when i remember that it's not there, i need to click over to the plan then and select it. lots of times when i'm looking at a failed build (maybe i got there from the link in the email) i decide i need to trigger a manual build. this would seem to be a natural place to have the menu.
fields.summary: Add "Build Actions" menu to Build Results page

fields.description:
When changes in a project is detected it should also trigger a check in it's parents. If changes in it's parents are detected they will get built first.

This would eliminate a lot of the errors we get because of the wrong build order. We have about 20 Maven 2 managed projects, and especially when there is a change in one of the util (cross cutting) projects that is commited together with changes in any of the domain projects we get errors because the util project is not built first.
fields.summary: Checking parent projects for changes before build
